titlestmt.title: PCT 24: A Blackfoot Adulteress and her Salteau Husband
titlestmt.author: Mrs. Maggie Achenam

bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

body.head: PCT 24: A Blackfoot adulteress and her Salteau husband

p.seg: kêtahtawê êsah iskwêw mistahi kiyiskwêw , êkwah êh-onâpêmit pikw âwiyah nâpêwah oskinîkiwah , êkwah êh-âyimisit . Once upon a time, the story goes, a certain woman was very silly; she would consort with any man or youth, and she was very troublesome.
kêtahtawê wâpamik owîkimâkanah kotakah ; misi-pakamahok . Once her husband caught her with another man and gave her a sound beating.
sipwêhtêw . She went away.
apsîsiyiwah ocôwâsimisah ; nayômêw êwakonih . She had a small child, which she carried on her back.
kêtahtawê kâwi kîwêw ; kotakah wîwiyiwa onâpêmah ; kisiwâsiw . After a while she went back home; her husband had taken another wife; she was angry.
sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw ; kotakah iskwêwah sipwêhtahêw . The man went away; he took the other woman along with him.
êkwah nawaswêw aw îskwêw . Then that woman ran after them.

tâh-têpwâtêw ,
niwîh-wêpinâw awah kicawâsimis ! itêw . She kept calling to him, “I'll throw away your child!”
ahci pikôw sipwêhtêw nâpêw . The man went away just the same.
wâhya mtonih êy-ispatinâk , wêpinêw êkotê ocawâsimisah iskwêw awa . Far away on a hill that woman abandoned her child.
êkwah pê-kîwêw . Then she came back home.
êkwah ocawâsimisah nakatêw , ispatinâhk êh-wêpinât , êh-apisîsisiyit . She left her child, abandoning it on a hill, a baby.

seg.gloss: “To the wolves I feed this little girl.”

p.seg: êkwah nêtê kîwêpahtâw . Then she ran back yonder.
mêkwâc wîkiwâhk êh-apit , onâpêma takohtêyiwa . As she stayed there in their house, her husband arrived.
tâniwâ nitânis ? itik . “Where is my daughter?” he asked her.
nâs ! itik . “Go fetch her!” he ordered her.
misi-pakamahok mitonih . He gave her a terrible beating.
sipwêhtêw ; nâtêw otânisah . She went off; she went to fetch her daughter.
namoya miskawêw . She could not find her.
kotakah ayîsiyiniwah miskawêyiwah . Other people had found her.
takohtêw . She came back.
tâniwâh ? itik onâpêma . “Where is she?” her husband asked her.
âsay mina mitoni misi-pakamahok . Again he gave her a terrible beating.
âsay mina sipwêhtêw . He went away again.
êkwah aw îskwêw pimitisahwêw onâpêma . The woman pursued her husband.
kîwê ! itik . “Go home!” he bade her.
namoya ! pê-kîwê kiyâm ! itêw onâpêma . “No! Please come home!” she said to her husband.
êkwah iskwêw kotakah nâpêwah otihtik . Then another man came to where that woman was.

kont îtêw ,
namoya nimihtâtâw . She told him all kinds of things, “I am not sorry about him.

seg.gloss: I am glad he is gone.

p.seg: nawac kiyâ mistahi kisâkihitin , itêw ; I love you much more,” she told him;

seg.gloss: “This is the kind of thing I like.
Now let us go off to my house.

p.seg: takohtêwak wîkiwâhk iskwêw . They came to the woman's house.
êkwah êh-tipiskâk , nâpêw awa sipwêhtêw . Then, after dark, the man went away.
pêyakohkwâmiw aw îskwêw . The woman slept alone.
nîpâtipisk kîwêyiwa onâpêma . During the night her husband came home.
êkwah pimisiniyiwa wayawîtimihk ; kâh-kitôtik . He lay outside the tent; he conversed with her.
êkwah âwa onâpêmah ôhi ê-takosiniyit . But it was her husband who had arrived.

êkwah ,
namoya , itwêw nâpêw ; So now, “No,” said he;
âhpôh êtokê kiwîkimâkan ta-takosin , itêw . “Your husband may come, for all I know,” he told her.

namoya , itwêw iskwêw ,
aspin wâhyaw êh-atimohtêt . “No,” said the woman; “He has gone far away.”

seg.gloss: “Oh, no! I am afraid of your husband.”

p.seg: kiyâm pîhtokê ! itwêw iskwêw . “Do come in!” said the woman.

awa nâpêw ,
hâ , itwêw ,
nika-pîhtokân . “Well,” said the man, “I shall go in.”
êkwah mâh-mâsihêw iskwêw . Then the woman lay with him. LB on {mâh-mâsihêw}: Literally, “wrestle”; in the present sense a common and, strangely enough, euphemistic expression.

seg.q: êkâya sôhki pâhpi ; ta-takosin kinâpêm ; ka-pakamahokonaw .
seg.gloss: Do not laugh aloud; your husband will be coming; he will beat us.”

p.seg:
namoya , itwêw iskwêw ;
namoya . “No,” said the woman; “No.

seg.gloss: He is far away; he will not be coming.”

p.seg: âhci pokô mâsihêw nâpêwah ôhi . Still she lay with that man.
kêtahtawê êkwah ocihciyiw otinam ; ocahcanisiyiwa otinimêw . Presently she took his hand; she took a ring from his finger. LB: Our narratress forgets to develop this motif.

êkwah nâpêw ,
kâ wiyah ! kiwîkimâkan kika-pakamahok , takohtêci . Then the man, “Don't! Your husband will beat you when he comes.”
namoya ta-kîh-takohtêw , itêw . “He cannot possibly be coming,” she answered him.

seg.gloss: “Do you love your husband very much?”

p.seg: namoya , itwêw iskwêw ; “No,” answered the woman,

seg.gloss: I am glad he is gone.”

p.seg: kontah ê-kîh-mâtôhkâsôyân , êh-kotêsi-miywêyihtamân ê-sipwêhtêt , itêw . I only pretended to weep, but I was really glad when he went,” she told him. LB on {êh-kotêsi-miywêyihtamân}: The particle {kotêsi} here compounded with the verb is otherwise unknown to me and may be wrongly recorded.

seg.gloss: “So there we have it! So you really are as crazy as all that, Red-Glow!
This is the end of you.
Without delay now I shall kill you.”

p.seg: tâpwê pok ôtihtinêw ; kipihkitonênêw . And really he seized her; he began to choke her.

seg.gloss: “It was because I recognized you, and on purpose, that I spoke to you that way!”
“No! I shall beat you within an inch of your life.”

p.seg: mistahi kakwê-kwâpatahwêw . He beat her as if to knock the insides out of her.
êkosi isi piyis pônihêw . Then at last he left her alone.
êkwah nipâw . Then she slept.
êh-wâpaniyik tâni mina ôk-êsinâkosih ! When morning came, you would have wondered what she ever had looked like.
tâpiskôc askihk ôhkwâkan . Her face was like a kettle.
kêtahtawê êh-miyw-ayât êkwah , kâ-takosiniyit ayîsiyiniwah , ayahciyiniwah . Presently, after she had recovered, some people arrived, some Blackfoot.
nâh-nîmihitôwân . They held ceremonial dances.
êhag , itwêw . “Yes,” she said.
mâka wîpac pê-kîwêhkan , itâw . “But come home early,” he told her.

êhag
itwêw . “Yes,” she said.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . So off she went.
nîmihitôw êkwah , pêskis êh-nikamot . She danced and sang.
mistahi miyawâtam . She celebrated with zeal.
êkwah wîkiwâhk mâh-mâtôyiwah ocawâsimisah . But in their tent her child cried and cried.
piyis nâpêw kisiwâsiw . At last the man got angry.
mistik otinam êh-watihkwaniwiyik . He took a forked stick.
pôt ôhi owîkimâkanah mêkwâc nîmihitôyiwa . there was his wife still a-dancing.
sîhtawikwêhwêw , êkos îsih êh-nimitâsi-yâhkahwât . he caught her neck in the stick and shoved her that way out into the open.
hê , awênah môhcôhkâsôwak ? itwêw aw îskwêw ; “Hey, for whom am I pretending to be crazy?” cried the woman;
kôtatêh tôtam . She did not know what to do.
onâpêmah ôhi kîwê-yahkohok . Her husband shoved her along all the way home.
êkwah kisiwâk wîkiwâhk nistawêyimêw onâpêma . When they were near their tent, she recognized her husband.
pîhtokêw êkwah . Then she went in.
kostêw , ê-ntawi-nôhâwasot . She was afraid of him, and went and nursed her infant.

onâpêmah :
tânis ômah , kâ-mihkwâsikêw ? Her husband, “How now, Red-Glow?”
pimakôcin ; kôtatêh tôtam awa . She was at a loss; she did not know what to do, this woman.
kêtahtawê mînah kâ-mêtawêwiht wîkiwâhk . Presently they had games again, in their tent.
pêyak êkotah apiyiwa ocîmisima . One of her lovers was there.
nama kêkway nipiy , itwêw . “There isn't any water,” she said.
êkwah askihkwah otinêw ; nâtêw êkwah kônah . So she took her kettle; she went to fetch snow.
êkwah êh-pê-kîwêt , paspâpiw wîkiwâhk . Then, when she came back, she peeped into the tent.
wâpamêw ay ôhi ocîmisimah . She saw her lover there.
kêtahtawê pâh-paskiskam ; pîhtokê-pahkisin . Then suddenly she stumbled into the opening; she fell into the tent.

seg.gloss: “No! It was because you were peeping in at your lover!”

p.seg: kostêw êkwah onâpêmah ; wêwêkistikwânêyipiw . Now she feared her husband; she sat with her head wrapped up.

seg.gloss: “How comes it you are ashamed now, you lewd dog, Red-Glow?”

p.seg: êkwah êh-wâpaniyik sipwêhtêw ; tapasîw êkwah . Then in the morning she went away; she fled.
kâsôw . She hid herself.
tahto-kîsikâw pimohtêw , wayawîtimihk êh-nipât . She walked every day and slept out of doors.
kêtahtawê sâkêwêw , spatinâhk kâ-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwa êh-pâpayiyit . Presently she came out upon a place where she saw a man riding that way over a hill.
kâsôw . She hid.
iyikohk êk êh-wâpamât sipwêhtêw . When she saw him no longer, she went on. Book has no space between {êk} and {êh-wâpamât}.
âsay mînah ê-sâkêwêt , kâ-wâpamât âsay mna êh-pâpayiyit ; kâsôhtawêw . When she came out over the next hill, she saw him again riding toward her; she hid from him.
sipwêhtêw êk êh-wâpamât . She set out when she saw him no longer.
otihtam mîkiwâhpah mistah ê-mihcêniyikih . She reached a place where there were many tipis.
âsa mina êkotah otihtêw ocîmisimah . This time too she came to where her lover was.
papâ-kâtik . He hid her in different places.
mâka kotakah nâpêwah papâ-kwâsihik . but the other man kept her away from her husband.

sôskwâc êkwah ninipahik , itêyihtam ,
miskawicih . “Now he will kill me without delay,” she thought, “if he finds me.”
tapasîw otah . She fled.
mêkwâc êh-pimohtêt , kêtahtawê kâ-wâpamât ayîsiyiniwah . As she was walking along, presently she saw a man.
êh-wîh-tapasît , têpwâtik . When she made to run away, he called to her.

seg.gloss: You can't get away from me.”

p.seg: pôyôw êkosi ; pêhêw . So she stopped; she waited for him.
pê-takopayiyiwah ôtêh . He rode up to where she was.

seg.gloss: “Get ready; make your dress as light as you can.”

p.seg: êkwah omaskisinah otinam , otâsah mînah , oskocâkâs . Then she took her moccasins, and her leggings, and her blouse.
tahkopitam aspapiwinihk . She tied them to the saddle.

ôtah kwayask , itik ,
ispahtâh ! “Straight on in this direction,” he told her, “run!”
êkwah aniy ê-sipwêpahtât , itêh kâ-kîh-ôhtôhtêt êkot ê-ispahtât . So then she set out at a run, and ran in the direction from which she had come.
êh-têhtapiyit onâpêmah tipihêw . She kept up with her husband's horse.
câhkastêhôk . He kept prodding her in the back.
pêyahtik ê-wâpanipahtâcik , kêtahtawê êkwah tâpakwêwêpinik . When they had run at a slow pace until morning, suddenly he threw a line round her neck.
êkwah êkos îsi sôhki mitonih êh-pimipayiyit , êh-wayacâwipitikot . Then he began to ride at a swift pace, dragging her as she ran.
wîh-nipahatâhtam . She was almost dead for want of breath.
pôt ôhi mîkiwâhpah okistakêwih . there were very many tents.
nakîw êkwah nâpêw . Then the man halted.
postayôwinisê , itêw owîkimâkanah . “Put on your clothes,” he told his wife.
mostâpêkasêpiw . She sat there, naked.
êkwah nâpêw mâkwêyimôw . Then the man began to be worried.
piyis postasâkahêw . At last he made her put on her blouse.
êkwah kîwêwak . Then they went home.
êh-takohtêcik pîhtokêwak . When they got there, they went into the tent.
êkwah iskwêw âhkosiw mitonih . Then the woman was very sick.

êkwah nâpêw ,
tânisi êh-tôtawat kiwîkimâkan ? Then the man was asked, “What have you been doing to your wife?”

êkwah iskwêw ,
tânisi êh-tôtâsk kiwîkimâkan ôh-âhkosiyan ? Then the woman, “What did your husband do to you, that you are ill?”
mistahi nipimipahtân êh-mostâpêkasêyân , itwêw . “I had to run far in a naked state,” she said.

êkwah wîhtamawâw nâpêw ,
ê-sakâpêkipahat kiwîkimâkan kêkâc nipahatâhtam , itâw . Then the man was told, “Because you made your wife ran on a line, she is almost dead from loss of breath,” he was told.
êkwah namoya wîh-pîkiskwêw . Then he would not answer.
piyis miyw-ayâw iskwêw . At last the woman got well.
âsa mina sipwêhtêw . Again she set out.
kotakihk takosin . She arrived at another place.
wâpamêw ispatinâhk nâpêwah êh-ma-mâtoyit . She saw a man weeping on a hilltop.

seg.gloss: “What is it you are weeping over?”

p.seg: nisîm ê-kîh-nipahiht , itik . “Because my younger sister has been killed,” he told her.
êkosi êkwah kîwê-wîcêwêw . So then she went home with him.
itah ê-kih-minahoyit , êkotah mistahi otinam wiyâs , kwaskwêpayihôsah ê-nipahâyit . There where he had killed game, she took a large amount of meat, for he had killed a jumping-deer.

seg.gloss: “No doubt your sister-in-law will be glad when she sees you.”

p.seg: êkwah kîwê-wîcêwêw . Then she went home with him.
takohtêwak mîkiwâhpihk . They arrived at the tipi.

seg.gloss: So you are alive after all.

p.seg: namoya kinipahik kiwîkimâkan ! itik . Your husband has not killed you!” the other said to her.

êhag , itêw ;
êh-pê-tapasiyân . “No,” she answered her; “I ran away and came here.” This is the agreeing answer to a yes-or-no question; if the question, as here, is put negatively, {êhag} corresponds to our “No.” book missing final quote

seg.gloss: “Surely your husband will kill you, if he finds you;
He may well come here, for all I know.”

p.seg:
namoya , itwêw ;
namoya nika-kîh-miskâk . “No,” she answered the other; “He won't be able to find me.”
ahpôh êtokêh âsay takosin , itik . “For all I know he has already come,” the other told her.
wîpac nâpêsisah êh-pîhtokêyit âcimoyiwah êh-takohtêyit onâpêma . Soon a boy came into the tipi and said that her husband had come.
tapasî , nicâhkos , itik . “Flee, Sister-in-Law,” the other told her.
êhag , itik . “Very well,” the other told her.
êkwah kâtik . Then she hid her.
kêtahtawê kâ-pîhtokêyit . Presently he came into the tent.

seg.gloss: “She has not come here at any time.”

p.seg: sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw ; kotakihk mîna itohtêw . The man went away; he went to another place.
êkwah môskîw . Then she came forth.
kostêw ; êkwah môskîw ; tapasîw . She feared him; then she came forth; she fled.

kêtahtawê pasahcâhk êh-ayât ,
êhâh , kimiskâtin ! k-êtikot , otihtimanihk êh-otinikot onâpêmah . Then, at one time, when she was in a ravine, “Haha, I have found you!” said her husband, grabbing her by the shoulder.
pakamahok cîkahikani-pakamâkanis ohci . He struck her with a tomahawk.
cikahkwêpahok . He knocked her out of her senses.
âpisisin . She came back to consciousness.
kîhtwâm min asay pakamahok . Again he struck her.
êkwah kinwês namoya kiskisiw . Then for a long time she was senseless.
nakatik êkwah onâpêmah . Then her husband left her there.
miskâk ocâhkosah . Her sister-in-law found her.
ahpinihk kîwêcitâpâtik . On a hide she dragged her back to the tent.
namoya ksikisiw kinwês . For a long time she remained unconscious.
êkwah awa nahkawiyiniw tapasîw . Then that Salteau fled.
ninipahâw ! itêyihtam . “I have killed her!” he thought.
owîkimâkanah pôti mâkah âpisisiniyiwah . But his wife recovered her senses.

seg.q: êkây êkwah , miyw-âyâyinih , êkâya wîkim kîhtwâm .
seg.gloss: “Now, when you get well, do not live with him any more.”

p.seg: êhag , itwêw . “No,” she said.
êkwah awa nâpêw sipwêhtêw . Then the man went away.
kotakah iskwêwah ta-kâ-kwâsihêw êh-onâpêmiyit . He decided to abduct another woman, who was married.
iskwêsisah ayâwêyiwah . This woman had a little girl.
êkwah awa kâ-kwâsihtwât mâh-mâtôyiwah mânah ocânisah . Then, when the husband was robbed of his wife, his little daughter used to weep.
pakwâtam . He did not like that.
êkwah êh-pimipiciwiht wâpamêw owîkimâkanah . Then, when the band moved camp, he caught sight of his wife.
mâh-mâtôh ! itêw . “Weep!” he told her.
namoya , itwêw iskwêw . “No,” said the woman.
kisiwâsiw ; mistahi kîhkâmêw onâpêma . She got angry; she scolded her husband severely.
miton êh-pakwâtitân , êyak ôhci kotak nâpêw k-ôh-otinak , itêw . “Because I hate you is why I have taken another man,” she told him.
kîskahwêw ohkwâkaniyihk . she cut open his face.

êkwah nâpêw ,
wêsâmihk êkwah kikîskahon ! Then the man, “So you even wound me!”
tapasîw aw îskwêw ; sipwêhtêw . The woman fled; she went from that place.
otinam nâpêw pâskisikan ; pîhtâsôw . The man took a gun and loaded it.
nawaswâtêw . He ran after her.
mihcêt ayîsiyiniwak êh-pimipicicik êkotah êh-pimohtêyit owîkimâkanah pâskiswêw ; As his wife was walking with a great band of people that were moving camp, he shot her;
kawiwêpahwêw . he felled her.
kinipahin ! itêw onâpêma . “You have killed me!” she said to her husband.

seg.gloss: “But that is just what I am trying to do!”

p.seg: êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then he departed.
pimisiniyiwa owîkimâkana . His wife lay there.
nipahêw kêkâc . He had nearly killed her.
kotakah ayîsiyiniwah otinik ; pôsihik . Other people took her up; they placed her on a vehicle.
êkwah êh-kapêsihk kêkâc nipiw . By the time they made camp, she was nearly dead.

êkwah niwîkimâkan nika-wâpamik , itwêw ,
mînah tânis . “Please have my husband see me,” she said, “and my daughter.

seg.gloss: I am surely going to die.”

p.seg:
namoya , itwêw ;
namoya ; namoya nka-kî-nitawâpamâw . “No,” he said; “No; I shall not by any possibility go to see her.”
piyis kêkâc êh-wâpahk nipiw iskwêw . At last, just before daylight, the woman died.
êkosi piciwak ayîsiyiniwak . Thereupon the people moved camp.
nama nânitaw itêyihtam nâpêw . The man did not think anything of it.
êkwah êh-kapêsihk , êkwah kîsitêpôw nâpêw ; Then, when they had pitched camp, he cooked a ceremonial meal;
wîhkohkêw . he invited guests.
mihcêt iskwêwak nitomêw . He invited many women.
êkwah k-ôh-nitômitakok , niwîkimâkan niwîh-mawîhkâtâw , itwêw . “The reason I have invited you is that I want to do mourning for my wife,” he said.
êkwah ocayânisiwâwah wîkiwâw kawinamwân , êh-mêkit kahkiyaw . Then their belongings and their tipi were thrown down, and he gave everything away.
nayêstaw otakohpis êyakô pimiwitâw , ocânisah mînah . Only his blanket he kept with him, and his little daughter.
nama kêkway pîtos kêkway ayâw êyakô ê-kîh-nipahât wîwah . Nothing else did he keep who had slain his wife.

mêkwâc kâ-nâh-nôtinitocik ayahciyiniwak , nânitaw ayênâniw-mitanaw askiy êyakw ânimah kâ-kîh-ispayik . At the time when the Blackfoot were fighting among themselves, about eighty years ago, was when this happened.
tapwê êsah kîh-kitimahêw ocânisah êh-kîwâtisihât . Truly, he brought misery upon his little daughter, making her an orphan.
